text.content: CKAD Guide: A Roadmap to Kubernetes Certification

title.plain_text: CKAD Guide: A Roadmap to Kubernetes Certification

text.content: Readers who want to get adequate knowledge on Kubernetes for their application deployments, especially people looking for a guide to pass Kubernetes Application Developer Certification. This post does not cover cluster management concepts but can be used as a starting point for Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA) exam as well‚Ä¶

rich_text.plain_text: Readers who want to get adequate knowledge on Kubernetes for their application deployments, especially people looking for a guide to pass Kubernetes Application Developer Certification. This post does not cover cluster management concepts but can be used as a starting point for Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA) exam as well‚Ä¶

text.content: So recently, I achieved CKAD certification in which I scored 96 out of 100. Since then a number of people have inquired me about the various sources I used and even the exam itself. So I ¬†thought of writing a post encapsulating everything I suppose is key to passing the exam.

rich_text.plain_text: So recently, I achieved CKAD certification in which I scored 96 out of 100. Since then a number of people have inquired me about the various sources I used and even the exam itself. So I ¬†thought of writing a post encapsulating everything I suppose is key to passing the exam.

text.content: In order to score well, not that it matters much, as qualifying marks are 66 out of 100; You need to focus on the following few broad categories -

rich_text.plain_text: In order to score well, not that it matters much, as qualifying marks are 66 out of 100; You need to focus on the following few broad categories -

text.content: Let's look at each of them, one by one. I won't be discussing the individual concepts in detail, instead, I'll attach the sources where you can get more wholesome material on the topic. But first, let me tell you about the exam itself.

rich_text.plain_text: Let's look at each of them, one by one. I won't be discussing the individual concepts in detail, instead, I'll attach the sources where you can get more wholesome material on the topic. But first, let me tell you about the exam itself.

text.content: CKAD is one of the three exams, pertaining to Kubernetes, sponsored by Linux Foundation. This particular certification tests one's ability to incorporate Kubernetes support in your application and not necessarily actual management of a Kubernetes cluster (we have CKA for that).

rich_text.plain_text: CKAD is one of the three exams, pertaining to Kubernetes, sponsored by Linux Foundation. This particular certification tests one's ability to incorporate Kubernetes support in your application and not necessarily actual management of a Kubernetes cluster (we have CKA for that).

text.content: This exam is completely practical and does not have any MCQs or subjective questions. We get a virtual machine terminal with 4 attached clusters and multiple namespaces. We then need to create/modify Kubernetes resources as directed in the questions. Speed plays a critical role as you need to solve 15-20 questions within 120 minutes.

rich_text.plain_text: This exam is completely practical and does not have any MCQs or subjective questions. We get a virtual machine terminal with 4 attached clusters and multiple namespaces. We then need to create/modify Kubernetes resources as directed in the questions. Speed plays a critical role as you need to solve 15-20 questions within 120 minutes.

text.content: Next, let's look at what you need to practice from containerization's point of view.

rich_text.plain_text: Next, let's look at what you need to practice from containerization's point of view.

text.content: Containerization is defined as¬†a form of operating system virtualization, through which applications are run in isolated user spaces called containers, all using the same shared operating system (OS).

rich_text.plain_text: Containerization is defined as¬†a form of operating system virtualization, through which applications are run in isolated user spaces called containers, all using the same shared operating system (OS).

text.content: Code editors such as VS Code and Atom have pampered us for easier User Interfaces. But they are not available in the CKAD environment. I suggest spending some time getting familiar with the VIM editor.

rich_text.plain_text: Code editors such as VS Code and Atom have pampered us for easier User Interfaces. But they are not available in the CKAD environment. I suggest spending some time getting familiar with the VIM editor.

text.content: Yes, there will be a notepad, but it's not of much utility.

rich_text.plain_text: Yes, there will be a notepad, but it's not of much utility.

text.content: Since this is a completely practical exam, getting your hands dirty is a must. You can use the below methods to set up a practice cluster

text.content: Make bookmarks out of the below documentation links. Although you can open only a single tab, no one is stopping you from clicking bookmarks. This is generally faster than searching for a particular Kubernetes Resource.

text.content: Make sure to do the below configurations at the beginning-

rich_text.plain_text: Make sure to do the below configurations at the beginning-

text.content:
# Create vim config file
vim ~/.vimrc


# Add below lines to the file
set tabstop=2
set expandtab
set shiftwidth=2

rich_text.plain_text:
# Create vim config file
vim ~/.vimrc


# Add below lines to the file
set tabstop=2
set expandtab
set shiftwidth=2

text.content: You can learn these but that's really not necessary as you'll get a hang of it after frequent use.

rich_text.plain_text: You can learn these but that's really not necessary as you'll get a hang of it after frequent use.

text.content:
alias k="kubectl"
alias kns="kubeclt config set-context --current  --namespace"
alias kdp="kubectl describe pod"
alias kdd="kubectl describe deployment"
alias kdf="kubectl delete pod --force --grace-period=0"

# Below varialble to be used while generating yaml file
export do="--dry-run=client -o yaml"

rich_text.plain_text:
alias k="kubectl"
alias kns="kubeclt config set-context --current  --namespace"
alias kdp="kubectl describe pod"
alias kdd="kubectl describe deployment"
alias kdf="kubectl delete pod --force --grace-period=0"

# Below varialble to be used while generating yaml file
export do="--dry-run=client -o yaml"

text.content: Preparing for the CKAD exam will propel your abilities as a DevOps Engineer. Kubernetes is a highly sought-out activity in the industry.

rich_text.plain_text: Preparing for the CKAD exam will propel your abilities as a DevOps Engineer. Kubernetes is a highly sought-out activity in the industry.

text.content: You will learn about how various components of computing infrastructure come together to support a product. This will require fine-tuning resource requirements, managing network, and user accesses, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: You will learn about how various components of computing infrastructure come together to support a product. This will require fine-tuning resource requirements, managing network, and user accesses, etc.

text.content: Every company wants its product to be resilient. You can help them achieve that!
